title: In search for campaign cash, de Blasio lands in middle of Orthodox battlefield
text:
Allegations aside, the fundraising push is yet another example of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio relying on contributions from New York donors who appear more interested in what he can do for them in City Hall than the White House. | AP Photo/Steven Senne In search for campaign cash, de Blasio lands in middle of Orthodox battlefield

NEW YORK — Mayor Bill de Blasio’s quest for campaign donations has entangled his presidential bid in a decades-long dispute over succession rights in New York City's Orthodox Jewish Satmar community.

What began as a request for contributions to qualify for the upcoming primary debates has become the latest chapter in the family feud, with accusations of pay-to-play deals, forged emails and a character assassination scheme.

Story Continued Below

Allegations aside, the fundraising push is yet another example of de Blasio relying on contributions from New York donors who appear more interested in what he can do for them in City Hall than the White House.

As POLITICO reported earlier this month, Satmar community leaders circulated a request on the secure messaging tool WhatsApp for $1 donations to help de Blasio get the 130,000 required contributors to qualify for the September debate. The request said the goal wasn’t to support the long-shot presidential bid, but rather to get in his good graces.

Another email and fliers soon appeared to follow, carrying a much more direct implication of quid pro quo.

“Please help out with the one-dollar campaign so that he can get into the Democratic debate,” reads an image of a poster emailed to POLITICO, according to a translator who is fluent in Yiddish. | POLITICO

“Please help out with the one-dollar campaign so that he can get into the Democratic debate,” reads an image of a poster emailed to POLITICO, according to a translator who is fluent in Yiddish. “The mayor promises that the new [synagogue] will be open for [us] ahead of the upcoming Sukkos holiday.”

A similar email sent to POLITICO said, “the mayor promised great favors” including a “promise to remove the ban on entering our holy community’s new bet midrash,” where religious studies are conducted. “Now you have the chance, once and for all, to save the future. Don’t miss [the] opportunity.”

The synagogue in question, a hulking frame of a building occupying a half-block in South Williamsburg, is at the center of a bitter fight that has split the Satmars in two. Aaron Teitelbaum heads up one sect while his brother Zalman leads the other, and each believes he is the rightful successor to their late father’s leadership post — and the site on Bedford Avenue.

The correspondence, professionally translated by Arun Viswanath for POLITICO, indicates the Zalman faction secured a commitment from de Blasio to have his Department of Buildings allow construction to move forward on the property, which has been stalled for a decade by a stop-work order.

The mayor’s office insists that is not the case.

“Any allegations of quid pro quo activity are completely false and inaccurate. As always, decisions are made strictly based on merit,” said mayoral spokesperson Avery Cohen. The stop-work order is still in place.

Representatives of the Zalman faction went a step further, alleging it was a setup orchestrated by their rivals.

“It’s doctored. There’s no such email. It’s doctored. It’s a fact,” Abe Deutsch, a politically active Satmar, told POLITICO in an interview. “The mayor is a very smart person and he’s not going to do things that are not according to the law and we are not going to ask him something that is not according to the law.”

“He’s not going to do crazy things. He’s running for president,” he added. “All eyes are open on him.”

He said a real email would have included a link to the mayor’s fundraising page.

“It would be nice if [they] wanted to do damage, at least let the mayor get a few dollars,” he added. “You want to do damage to him, at least let him get $50.”

POLITICO reached out to the email address from which the fundraising plea came. A reply echoed Deutsch’s comments: “We are aware of forged emails and posters that were spread in an obvious attempt to hurt us and the de Blasio campaign.”

However, a representative from the Aronite section of the community shot back that there was no forgery, and that the group was not involved in any fundraising for the mayor's presidential campaign.

“I have no clue,” Rabbi Moishe Indig, who represents the followers of Aaron, said in an interview. “I don’t know anything about it.”

The rewards of wading into the dispute have thus far been lackluster for de Blasio, who hopes to qualify for another debate scheduled for October. A fundraising page set up by the Satmar community on ActBlue.com showed 682 contributions for a total of $877 as of Thursday — far short of the stated 10,000 donation goal.

The mayor has publicly distanced himself from big money in politics and characterized his campaign as grassroots. However, nearly all of the cash he has been using to travel around the country and meet voters in early primary states has come from a small group of donors in New York City real estate, finance and legal circles. Some of those have business before the city.

In addition, the mayor’s questionable use of two political action committees has already netted a formal complaint to the Federal Election Commission.
description: What began as a request for contributions to qualify for the upcoming primary debates has become the latest chapter in a family feud.
